pros:
- Some of the best researchers work there! 
- There exist some employment guidelines that can respect some of the employees rights …
- Their trade union team is very helpful
cons:
- Poor management style, between vague feedback, incorrect information and advice, rushed decisions with no fair and transparent investigation, and an authoritative rather than a collaborative mode of working.
- An environment that does not appreciate the skillsets of their employees, nor the ownership that researchers need to do their research.
- Lack of technical data, most of the work is about literature reviews and convening of events.
- Must be fully aware of your rights in a very detailed manner as an employee to be able to survive in this environment.
- Quite undermining in terms of career progression. Pay level often does not match the right market pay for the job seeker, and lack of a systematic and regular pay progression. 
- Received some remarks that are discriminatory for other backgrounds.

pros:
You get to work with some really passionate and intelligent people. There are a lot of strong women in the teams. The work is interesting and you get to try new topics. There are social groups such as softball, podcast society, etc. that bring people together. 

Chill casual academic environment. Nice roof deck.
cons:
Below average pay that isn't pegged to inflation (so your real wages actually decrease every year). No pay progression (you need to wait 2 years, and this isn't guaranteed given the uncertain finances of the company). No bonuses. No clear promotion policy (you have to apply if a position opens up, otherwise you could be stuck in your role).

High turnover rate. This contributes to the already low morale.

A high-stress environment where everyone is trying to cover their days with projects, at the same time, are pressed to pitch for projects with fewer days to win projects. So the result is stress if you have too much work and stress if you don't have enough work.

The margins on the work are high to cover operational costs so projects are lost due to uncompetitive bids. At the same time, the organization is cutting on vital publications and communications support so the teams do not even feel those margins at work.

pros: Good and friendly people. In particular, HR, Finance and IT people are fantastic.
cons:
Some job titles are misleading, particularly for program management roles. These jobs are essentially administrative work, and it kills your career prospectus if you are joining from NGO / UN / philanthropy / consultancy backgrounds. I swiftly left the organization after I noticed the reality. This explains the reasons why salary is very low  at ODI, benefits are non existent (no private health insurance, no eye check up, non dental coverage.. nothing!!) and so many inexperienced young people are working in these capacities (but they seem to think they are thematic experts).  It's admin, full stop.

Another issue is that ODI does not take unconscious bias seriously. I heard unaccceptable remarks from white staff without being aware it is crossing the line, and also experienced micro aggressions (e.g. no "thank you" when door is held; ignore your greetings; no invitation to social if you are not from certain backgrounds). It is a predominantly white organization, so perhaps this does not come as an issue at the moment, but it should.

pros: ODI has had a difficult two years but is really bouncing back after a period of transformation and regrouping. As a result of the change there was a dip in morale, some who couldn't  stomach the changes left the organisation. Others have stayed and helped the organisation turn the corner and get its focus back. It has meant that there have been numerous changes but is has settled down. ODI does great work in the world and once again its work is being rewarded on so many levels. I really enjoyed my time at ODI , my colleagues were great. Yes some researchers are a little pretentious, but on the whole they are great. The support services, HR, Facilities, Finance and   IT are also good to work with. The finance systems are improving but they are frustrating !!.  The diversity of the staff is a real bonus. It was great working with such a diversely educated workforce, very empowering.
cons: As a result of the financial issues and the lack of leadership  from the ED it was a bumpy ride for a while. The interim ED's and SLT are turning its fortunes around. Don't work at ODI if you don't want to put in a lot of work, however the rewards are great.

review_title: The cattiest, most elitist place you will ever work
pros:
You won't struggle to find kind and inspiring people to work with.
Whatever your speciality in international development, the subject matters are always interested.
This institution has amazing security protocol for researchers. They take care of you.
Fantastic office and location.
cons:
Top management are the most two-faced, catty individuals you will ever have the displeasure of working with. They're all talking badly of each other, all trying to take the other down to get the top position. 

They live in this primarily white, elite, Oxbridge-bubble and if you're not part of that circle and work in an administrative capacity like I did, they will make you feel like a worm. There will be little to no training, no assistance for development, and no consideration for work-life balance. Don't bother confiding in a single one of them, not even if it concerns your own health. Everything you share will be used against you.

The lack of respect astounded me. This is supposed to be a humanitarian organisation, they're supposed to have seen the worst and best of humanity. Shouldn't that make you a kinder, more humble person? Management seemed more concerned with their own image as humanitarian superstars.

pros:
Good working culture - flexible working environment, friendly colleagues, lots of very smart people. Nice building - though many staff work from home or nearby cafes when it suits them also. Casual dress code, a lot of independence in work/building your portfolio. High profile events hosted regularly that are interesting to attend. Publications get a lot of communications support and it helps to improve your profile. Lots of travel if you want it.

On the cutting edge of the most interesting development issues, and people want to hear what the organisation has to say.
cons:
Low salaries compared to consultancy work. Long working hours and high stress at times (10-14 hours/day not unusual during busy periods). 

Each team is quite different within ODI, so your team culture depends which boss you are working to. Business model means you need to bring in work if you are in the more senior levels of staff. You have to bill your time to donors, which can be stressful.

No formal postings to other countries though some staff do work overseas for long periods.

pros: i have worked at ODI for nearly 6 years and hope to work here for a lot longer. its great to have all our support under one roof and we get to find out about the work the researchers do in ODI. its very rewarding. i feel like we are one big team instead of separate departments.
cons: i understand ODI is going through a tough time at the moment but i believe cutting out pay rises and promotions are not giving everybody the drive to do more/ better. you hear alot of people around the building complaining about this.

pros:
- The organisation is filled with some of the smartest, most hard working individuals you will ever meet.

- They're very good with providing a flexible working environment, particularly if you have a young family. 

- The office itself is stunning and very central, with views of the shard and many shops and restaurants nearby.

- There are a great many training, learning & development programs on offer. They really encourage career progression.
cons:
- The biggest problem with ODI is the petty politics. There's a great deal of backstabbing and favouritism, especially as far as management are concerned.
ODI is a charity and we're all there to help those who really need it. Put aside your massive egos for a second, stop wasting time getting offended over nothing and get on with things. 

- The HR and Communications departments are a real mess, with low staff retention and erratic organisation. 

- Working hours can be very long in order to meet great demands. That wouldn't be so much of a problem if there was a real structure in place which ensured everyone got paid overtime, but funnily enough only HR and Facilities seem to have this privilege.

- It's very London-centric and has a very specific, 'high-brow' audience, so they're aiming their campaigning towards people that already agree with them. They need to branch out from their friend circles more.

pros: ODI is a smaller but influential and a powerful version of the United Nation in the UK. There is great work being done, hardworking people and a vision to make the world a better and safer place.

review_title: Dynamic organisation with enthusiastic employees and a focus on participation
pros:
The most rewarding thing about working at ODI is the opportunity to engage with talented and experienced colleagues on stimulating projects and the continuous learning opportunities that this generates. 

After a uncharacteristically difficult year, ODI is now firmly back to its dynamic ways with a number of high-profile and forward-looking research projects won since January 2019. 
The new leadership (in acting-up capacity since January 2019) also initiated a comprehensive change process that has employee participation at its very core. The process is led by six teams staffed by employees from different team and job specialisms. Their remit is to bring the process to the wider staff for a bottom-up approach to creating lasting and effective change at ODI in areas ranging from business processes and systems to career development and rewards. 

Given the high success rate in winning contracts, the leadership's drive to ensure a participatory approach to the restructure process and the resources that are being invested in new financial and project management systems, the feeling at ODI is that of an extremely positive outlook. This is compounded by enthusiastic staff that are continuing to work passionately on their projects and whilst providing inputs to address the aspects of the organisation that need to be improved to enable ODI to grow and increase its outreach.
cons: The participatory change process is currently quite intensive and places considerable demands on already busy staff.  Despite this, staff have clearly shown their support for this bottom-up approach through their commitment. This is, however, temporary and, indeed, some of the areas under review are work/life balance and ensuring a manageable workload.

pros:
ODI is a good brand in the development sector. 
Work flexibility.
Nice office location.
cons:
The PM role is 80% administration. Quite boring if you come from an international NGO. Average life for a PM in ODI is 2 year.
Researcher usually don't have good PM skills, therefore your role is to correct their mistakes.
Systems are really poor, there is a lot of duplication and a lot of manual entry.

pros: Slightly flexible on working hours, if you are lucky, you can have a small good team around you
cons:
There seems to be an group of individuals in management who are very buddy-buddy and somehow these individuals ave all managed to get at least 2 promotions within a space of two years and huge pay rises at the same time. The number of ethnic minorities in management and board level is extremely low in comparison to general staff  and the areas of work involved. I have seen white staff being promoted over non-white staff in some circumstances and yet those who knew the non-white staff would say that individual was a more stronger candidate than the white member of staff. ODI has huge turn-overs. Each month at-least 4 staff leave and arrive considering ODI staff is only 200 head count, or there about. A lot of people even question the work ODI does and does it really have any benefits? Researches spend far more time at their desks in London than do they do in the field, yet they describe themselves as experts.
Funds are wasted. I have been told by some research staff that a lot of the trips they do abroad is unnecessary and they could have done so other more economical means. The carbon footprint is huge due to the number of unnecessary overseas trips staff, yet they have a huge Climate team. Some staff try and use and abuse the lack of a expenses policy at ODI, which is shocking, both the fact that ODI does not have a clear expenses policy and that staff try and abuse this. It has been known that staff have blatantly tried to claim travel expenses of items they know is questionable. One example was a staff member claimed for having a head massage due to their flight being cancelled and as a result they had a migraine and need the massage to help them!!
